ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Familiarize yourself with the works of renowned American and Hispanic authors.

An introduction to some of the great works of American literature! I loved being able to read such profound work in Spanish, and it was really interesting to see the connections between the works originally written in English and those originally written in Spanish.
Read a wide range of literature from both North and South America that I had previously never had the opportunity to explore before. I am excited to continue exploring these authors over the summer.
My reading skills improved SO much. I have never read such challenging literature (or canonical literature) in Spanish, let alone doing much of that in English.

This course is a wonderful synthesis of literary styles and themes between North and South American literature. We went in in-depth analyses of various short-stories and novels, analyzing Spanish-written and translated texts.

This class offered me a wonderful opportunity to read closely and engage in thorough discussions of literature. The course improved my abilities to absorb large amounts of Spanish language prose, and allowed me to draw connections between texts.
I learned a lot about some literary classics and about the Spanish language.

Reading skills in Spanish were strengthened in this class. Writing skills were as well, but not to the same extent, understandably so. Professor Adorno's ability to help out with reading skills is really quite underrated.
Improved knowledge of Spanish language, understanding of interconnected aspects of literature of North and South America
This is a good class with a great reading list.
This course helped me improve my reading and comprehension skills in Spanish, and the in-class conversations enabled me to get a better command of the spoken Spanish language.
We read and analyzed number of influential American and Latin American works, as well as gained insight into the connections between these genres.

I was able to learn sharpen my Spanish comprehension skills through the short stories and books that we read. I also learned about various Latin American authors and their connection to American (U.S.) authors in their writing
I strengthened my reading skills in Spanish and learned about common themes in North American and South American literature.
Improving skill in reading and interpreting complex Spanish.

I loved how Adorno was able to connect classic literature from North America and Latin America and highlight the themes that were prevalent in both. In addition to learning the plots and characters from some of the most famous novels and stories of the Americas, we also learned how to read carefully, looking for allusions and hints in the writing.

This class was enjoyable and insightful. I was encouraged to analyze literature in Spanish just as I would in any English class, which gave me the same skills I needed to either write argumentative essays or in this case, create a script for a play. Managing the same literary devices I was taught in English in a Spanish class was very useful in aiding Spanish reading skills. I felt far more comfortable picking up Spanish literature after I took this class.
I definitely improved in my ability to read Spanish literature.
I learned how to analyze literature in Spanish, and analyze it to the point of reflecting upon it creatively.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think there's great exposure to many interesting short stories and novels from famous authors. For the novels, it is more difficult to discuss them in their entirety in the lecture slides so we tended to only cover certain passages from our reading assignment.

Strengths: Professor and TA are very kind, and extremely passionate about the subject material. Great reading list as well. Weaknesses: Im not sure how well the combined lecture-seminar format worked. I think the course would have functioned much better as either a lecture, or a limited enrollment seminar - 35 students is a bit too large for a discussion based course.

For anyone who loves reading and literature, this is an amazing class that really taught me to appreciate literature.  The class was a little big so it was sometimes hard to participate, but I loved being able to read the text out loud in class and see the beauty of the words.  I also enjoyed the collaborative work, since it allowed me to talk to my classmates and see all of their wonderful creativity!

The class size made it a bit difficult to fully express oneself because it was a bit intimidating in a class where skill level varied greatly. In addition, it often meant that it could sometimes be difficult to find a time to jump into the conversation. I loved the fact that Professor Adorno and Esteban (our TF) were always available to discuss any questions we had about the course or just to simply discuss the reading materials.
We were helped to ease us in by structuring the course with lighter readings at the beginning. The escenficaciones are a lot of fun and divided well throughout the semester.

The strengths of this course are the diverse course material and wonderful teaching of Dr. Adorno. Her style is wonderful and easy to follow along. This course can be improved with small group discussions in the form of break-out rooms or small group discussions if in person. This would give students more ability to analyze and engage with the texts together.

I really enjoyed how Professor Adorno sent out PDFs of the texts/class notes so that we could engage in very focused readings. However, I felt the class was too big to provide all students enough time to really engage with the material verbally. It was less of a conversation and more of a lecture, which is not necessarily a weakness, just an element of the class and the demand.

The professor was so engaged in the lectures and she really made sure to make the presentations in a way that could help us understand the literature better because they were sometimes difficult to understand. She was also open to all ideas.
Strengths: Professor Adorno and Esteban are wonderful, caring instructors. Weaknesses: the course runs like a seminar, but there were 40+ students, so not everyone could participate each class.

Srengths: 
- The professor's personality is amazing. 
- The work was quite low outside of class besides the reading (no tests, so that really took the stress off the shoulders and encouraged deeper engagement and reading
- Great TA
- She would always be helpful during her office hours if we had any concerns or questions. (Tbh, they were quite infrequent, once every two weeks, but she would be willing to have hold private meetings if one desired)

Weaknesses: It was online, so ya (to be expected). Make of that what you wish.
The main weakness of the course was the online format, which made the discussions harder to focus on, breakout rooms or activities may have helped this

I think it was weird because of COVID, but there were very very few assignments for the entire semester, which was great. The reading list was excellent, but I think I would have enjoyed this class much more if the English works were read in English instead of translated into Spanish.

Strengths: fantastic selection of texts, readings were always carefully selected to keep the reading very manageable, Professor Adorno is incredibly knowledgeable and has tons of energy, and the final assignment (performance of a literary passage) really enhanced my understanding of the material. V

Weaknesses: For the second half of the course (longer novels), the Powerpoint summaries were hard to follow.
Great for those who love reading fiction

Strengths: very understanding Professor and TA; the lectures were very helpful in understanding and deciphering the literature that we were reading; class discussions also helped bring new insights into view

Strengths:
- easy to follow
- clear organization of topics and learning
- final theater project is fun

Weakness:
- large amount of students, limited participation in class

One strength of the course is how in-depth the novels and stories are analyzed, as well as the context that is given before each class to not only explain the author's perspective and background, but also to help us better understand the setting and time period in which the story or novel takes place. One weakness is that since there were so many people in the course, it was sometimes hard to participate despite it being designed to be a seminar class. As such, I didn't get a chance to develop my own ideas about the stories we read as much as I would have liked.

The strength of this course is in the syllabus. All the readings are wonderful, and the course ends in "Cien anos de soledad" which is absolutely breathtaking. It is now one of my favorite books ever. I also really liked the 'escenificaciones' that we had to put on. It was awesome to extend the readings in a creative way. I think the weakness of this class was in the format. Going to class and just re-reading the pages that we had already read for homework was often boring. It got better as time went on, but definitely at the beginning, I was disappointed with how much we actually got to comment on and discuss things. I think things got better by the time we got to Garcia Marquez.
Prof Adorno is a wonderful person. The course was incredibly stale, however.

The readings were incredibly interesting and entertaining, which made the course generally engaging. A potential weakness of the course is that there isn't much comparison between North and South American authors specifically, but rather, comparison is more implied.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The Zoom raise your hand feature allowed students to participate willingly and helped organize an order which people would answer questions.
Uploading the Powerpoint slides prior to class was very helpful.  I think sharing the screen and choosing people to read worked well.
I loved our theatrical performances. I believe that it really allowed us to integrate and comprehend the relationships between the literature that we read over the semester.

The escenificaciones and active participation made it feel a bit less virtual. I was always engaged, even when my Spanish wasn't keeping up or I hadn't understood something it was a true process of learning and growth.
The use of Dr. Adorno's slideshow was helpful in engaging students with content.
I imagine the course would have even more robust discussions in person.

I wish that more people could have been called on to participate because I feel like the same people were called on each time. I felt like I had to try really really hard to be able to participate but since participation was a part of the grade I felt like I had to.
Project-based learning and group work was helpful during the pandemic. Professor Adorno also calls on people to read slides aloud, which helped ensure that everyone was participating on Zoom.

Her online acting presentations were very fun to perform and got to offer an insight as to how others were interpreting the works we had read. It made things just stick better as opposed to having an exam.
I thought the format worked well.
The escenificaciones were an amazing learning tool to allow students to engage in a new way with the texts and to bring the words to live in interesting ways. Please keep these in the future!

Our final presentations (escenificaciones) worked particularly well over Zoom (students were so creative and used virtual backgrounds, props, and costumes!) Breakout rooms would be appreciated if this course is virtual in the future.

I genuinely believe this class was taught to the best of its ability. Professor Adorno and Esteban were truly great lecturers and you can clearly see their passion for this class. You should never hesitate to reach out to either of them!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think for the student who is comfortable reading at a high level of Spanish, this course may be pretty enjoyable as the reading assignments aren't too long and we mostly discuss them openly throughout class. If you're hoping to practice speaking/writing, this course may not be suited to help you improve those areas. I thought it was a fine course to take for the Advanced Language Certificate requirement for a 300-level class.
If youre very interested in the topic, yes!
Yes! If you love reading literature, you should definitely take this.

Yes!!! I absolutely love Professor Adorno! You can tell that she is passionate about the subject, and actively wants to engage with the materials. She is always more than willing to meet and discuss the literature. Frankly, she has been one of my favorite professor's at Yale thus far.

Absolutely! Profesora Adorno is an effective lecturer and this is a great 300-level class to ease you into harder literature. If you're not interested in literature and are just looking for a Spanish class, I might look another direction.
Yes 100% you should take this course. One of the best Spanish literature courses at Yale and with the most amazing professor and TA!
I would very much recommend this course to another student! Prof. Rolena Adorno is simply the best!

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. Professor Adorno teaches with great care, ensuring her students fully understand the must crucial elements of the texts. The stories were quite good and I enjoyed her emphasis on careful, emotive reading out loud during class.
Yes.
Yesit's an enjoyable way to read and discuss some classics and practice your Spanish skills.

Yes. 

If you have any desire to learn more about literature, it is the course for you. The professor is wonderful and makes it easy to stay engaged.
I would recommend this course because of the interesting books.
Yes, but it could be totally different after the pandemic ends.
Absolutely. It's a privilege to learn from Professor Adorno.

Absolutely! This course is a great balance of a very (VERY) manageable workload and interesting topics. First off, the selection of texts is fantastic. The readings were all super enjoyable and I never knew there could be so many connections between US and Latin American works. Professor Adorno did an incredible job assigning specific selections, and short stories, so we could focus on a shorter text rather than getting lost in a very long reading assignment. Class was thought-provoking and lively, although sometimes the Powerpoint-and-discuss format got a bit dry. Professor Adorno has an incredible amount of energy and really cares for her students, and this is clear throughout the course. I'm not sure how this course would be in a normal year, but Prof. Adorno really took student needs into consideration and left the only graded assignments as a few tiny writing commentaries and a group skit that was actually really fun and a good way to get to know the works. Accordingly, this was the lowest-pressure class I've taken at Yale and nonetheless I learned a lot and loved doing the readings even too. Highly recommend this class for anyone who wants to take a Spanish course.
Yes, great for students that want to read great works of fiction and discuss them, as well as students looking to maintain / improve their speaking abilities and reading comprehension
Yes, specifically to students who are interested in utilizing their Spanish to understand literature that discusses narratives about Latin America

I would recommend this course to another student. Mostly because i think that Cien aos de soledad is an amazing book, and learning about some background in literature as well as comparing it to North American literature makes it much better still.  But you can also just read these books on your own.
I would definitely recommend this course!

Yes! It's a great class to take to better understand and improve upon your Spanish critical thinking skills. It's a fun and insightful class that will make you think every day, and the work is always reasonable!
I think I would. I hope that in person class is a little more engaging, but I honestly think it's worth it either way just for the books and stories that we read.
NO. You just read off slides all class.
Yes! It is an interesting course and the literature is very enjoyable.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This was a virtual seminar/lecture course. Based on the class size fo 37 people, I would argue it is leaning more towards lecture-size. However, Professor Adorno made it a very interactive environment where we could speak relatively freely, similar to a seminar environment.
fully virtual; mix between lecture and seminar
Outside comments of the reading. (notes, essentially)
Live virtual lecture, but with a good deal of student involvement and discussion
no other ones just live seminar discussions on zoom

Perusall
Canvas
n/a

        Literature of the Americas TR
